author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: BJP feels Sena may flail about but will not leave the coalition
text:
NEW DELHI: The BJP's frayed relations with its oldest ally are deteriorating, setting the stage for longish divorce proceedings while Shiv Sena, un-reconciled to playing second fiddle in the Maharashtra government, steps up the ante and looks to embarrass its alienated partner at every turn.
The assessment in BJP circles that Sena might flail and lash out but may not leave the coalition government in Maharashtra is based on the view that the party has little to gain by exchanging ministerial positions for the leader of opposition's post in the assembly.
It is more likely, feel BJP leaders, that Sena will continue it provocative ways, challenging chief minister Devendra Fadnavis's authority and opportunistically ally with other parties in Parliament as it did to oppose the land acquisition bill.
BJP's dilemma is that it does not want to be one to initiate a break. One ally less does not help its cause and the party doesn't see the merit of becoming dependent on the Nationalist Congress Party, an outfit seen to be singularly transactional about its politics.
The challenge for the Maharashtra government is in acting against Sena members responsible for the black paint attack on Sudheendra Kulkarni, a former aide of L K Advani, who were feted as heroes by party chief Uddhav Thackeray.
The task is not easy as Fadnavis had categorically said the attack on Kulkarni, for having organized a book release function of former Pakistan foreign minister Khurshid Mehmud Kasuri, has lowered Mumbai's prestige and promised action against those responsible.
Sena has thrown the gauntlet and Fadnavis and BJP will be under pressure to respond. The party is unlikely to do so in a hurry as that might precipitate a crisis at a time when BJP is in the midst of a crucial election in Bihar and does not have an alternate plan ready.
BJP can allow Sena to carry on with its intimidation only at the risk of its government in Maharashtra losing credibility, a development that can also impact efforts to woo domestic and foreign investment.
BJP's relations with Sena have had their tense moments, most famously when the late Balasaheb Thackeray was briefly arrested and let off on bail in 2000 over a case of alleged inflammatory writing. But on the whole, the alliance survived till the break before the 2014 assembly elections.
BJP leaders have pointed out that even if the Sena had accepted the final offer of seats for the assembly polls, it would have had its chief minister. Now, it must put up with Fadnavis while also having to contend with the breakaway MNS led by Raj Thackeray.
